the
computer um uh I used to do some
very specific drafts um starting out
with sort of a pre-draft that
was unfortunately referred to around the
house as the vomit out it was uh when I
got home from some from the reporting I
would write a version of of piece
without even looking at my notes I think
when I try to figure out what the
purpose of the of the vomit out was I
think I think it was to see uh kind of
inventory what was in my mind and also
see what what wouldn't work I mean which
which direction the piece had to go in
or did or couldn't go in um and it
started out in more or less English but
sort of disintegrated as I went so I was
always afraid when I wrote more at the
New Yorker instead of at
home I was all always afraid that some
cleaning woman would find one of the
vomit outs and and entertain the other
cleaning woman uh by reading it said and
he she'd say oh he calls himself a
writer and they would slap their brooms
against the desks like hockey players
and um uh I I would I actually often
didn't even look at it after I did it
the next day I would start on
the for 15 years I did a piece around
the country every three weeks from The
New Yorker and there was a day for each
one of these drafts and half of the
rough draft the next day and half and
then something called the yellow draft
that was different kind of paper um and
then typing up on the computer and when
I first started with a computer I
started more or less the same way I
would I would I use it as a fast
typewriter I would I would just print
out the draft and then start over again
uh start actually typing it over again
uh over the years I finally got weaned
from that and and now I guess the what
the people who know about computers
would say is that I compose on the
computer more than I did before um but
um so I I um I don't have any particular
ritual or anything like that uh I'm I'm
very sorry I don't have a complicated
ritual I I always said no writer ever
lost money taking himself too
seriously um so I wish I could tell you
that I stood on my head or something
like but I don't I just write whatever I
have to
write well you can erase it with a

the draft doesn't have to I used to just
um
uh take it out of the typewriter and and
rip the page and and staple it on and
then staple the next place so so you can
um I'm not so sure I I used to think
that that writing on a computer
encouraged fixity because you could you
could sort of move whole sections
instead of retyping them and um but I
think by now everybody's so accustomed
to
computers um and um uh
my thought process was pretty much tied
to the typewriter because I uh I grew up
in Kansas City and and
um you now occasionally uh read about
cities running out of money and closing
the schools but Kansas City was way in
the lead on this it ran out of money
when I was about an eighth grade and
closed the school and um my father
thought that kids shouldn't be out on
the street in April or whatever it was
so he sent my sister and me to sarasan
Huli secretarial school and um um then
we were I was I my sister was liberated
then which I which doesn't I've never
understood that because usually in that
era girls it was it was thought that
that was one of the skills that would
allow them to get work uh but I was made
to type every day for something so um
consequently my
um my thoughts have always been sort of
connected to to typing and uh there was
a time when if I had to write something
like a thank you note in long hand I'd
have to type it out first and then and
then copy it um but um I I I mean that
isn't true of a lot of people and and
now everybody types even business people
type I think what Fran Liebert said
about men isn't it amazing how fast they

fingers wouldn't work and all that then
